title.narrative: Parliamentarians for Global Action Core Support 2019-2021

description.narrative:
Insatsen avser ett kärnstöd till Parliamentarians for Global Action (PGA) om totalt 9 MNSEK för att implementera sin strategiska plan "Mobilizing Legislators as Champions for Human Rights, Democracy and Peace" under perioden 2019-2021.
Insatsen syftar till att mobilisera parlamentsledamöter att bidra till en internationell ordning baserad på internationella regelverk för en mer rättvis, säker och demokratisk värld. Detta genom arbete mot 8 målområden:
- Universalitet och effektivitet av Romstadgan av den internationella brottmålsdomstolen (ICC) och dess system - Universalitet och implementering av konventionen om biologiska och kemiska vapen (BWC) samt implementering av FN's säkerhetsrådsresolution 1540 (2004) - Förhindra den olagliga handeln med lätta vapen (SALW) samt förbättrad reglering av internationell vapenhandel för att förhindra övergrepp på mänskliga rättigheter - Stoppa barn- och tidiga tvingande äktenskap - Stoppa diskriminering på basis av sexuell orientering och genus identitet - Stoppa dödsstraffen - Skydd av haven och implementering av SDG 14 - Säkerställa att demokratiska normer, institutioner och civilt och politiskt utrymme, inklusive lagstiftares grundläggande rättigheter, är skyddade och uppehållna
PGA's totala organisationsbudget för projektperioden 2019-2021 är 62 MNSEK, av vilken PGA efterfrågar 9 MNSEK (14,5%) från Sida i kärnstöd. Den återstående delen planeras att täckas av medel från Danmark, Kanada, Nederländerna, Estland, Schweiz, Liechtenstein (Global Equality Fund), mellanstatliga organisationer som UNSCAR och EU kommissionen samt stiftelser och fonder så som Stewart R Mott Foundation, Arcus Foundation, CRDF Global, Oak Foundation, Open Society Foundations, Planethood Foundation, Raymond & Elizabeth Bloch Foundation och Sigrid Rausing Trust.

Parliamentarians for Global Action has applied to Sida for core funding of 9 million SEK to implement their strategic plan "Mobilizing Legislators as Champions for Human Rights, Democracy and Peace" during the period 2019-2021.
The intervention aims to moblize legislators to contribute to a rules based international order for a more equitable, safe and democratic world. PGA will work through campaigns focused at 8 overarching objectives:
- Universality and Effectiveness of the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (ICC) system - Universality and Implementation of the Biological and Toxin Weapons Convention (BWC) and Implementation of UN Security Council Resolution 1540 (2004) - Addressing the Illicit Trade in Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) and Improved Regulation of the International Arms Trade to Prevent Human Rights Abuses - Ending Child, Early and Forced Marriage (CEFM) - Ending Discrimination based on Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity (SOGI) - Abolition of the Death Penalty (ADP) - Protection of the Oceans and Implementation of SDG 14 (to conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas and marine resources) - Democratic Renewal and Human Rights (in development)
The Global Parliamentary Campaign for Democratic Renewal and Human Rights, is a new Campaign intended to contribute directly to PGA’s vision by supporting the networking mechanism among all parliamentary associations and legislative caucuses.
The interventions total budget for the period 2019-2021 is estimated to 62 million SEK contributed by Institutional donors, Foundations and other Private entities.

Parliamentarians for Global Action (PGA) is a non-governmental, multi-party, international network of legislators mobilizing parliamentarians in all regions of the world to advocate for human rights and rule of law, democracy, human security, inclusion and gender equality. Sida provides core support to PGA's strategic plan 2019-2021, which is aimed at contributing to PGA’s vision of a rules-based international order for a more equitable, safe and democratic world through its three programs as below. All programmes and actions of PGA are organized into results-oriented campaigns and PGA works with the following nine campaigns during the period 2019-2021 (the FAW campaign was added in 2020) within each of the three programs: - Core campaign on Democratic Renewal and Human Rights 1) International Law and Human Rights - Campaign of the Universality and Effectiveness of the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (ICC) system -Campaign for the Abolition of the Death Penalty (ADP) -Campaign for the Protection of the Oceans and Implementation of SDG 14 2) Gender, Equality and Inclusion -Campaign on Ending Child, Early and Forced Marriage (CEFM) -Campaign against Discrimination based on Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity (SOGI 3) International Peace and Security - Campaign to Address the Illicit Trade in Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) and Improved Regulation of the International Arms Trade to Prevent Human Rights Abuses - Campaign for Universality and Implementation of the Biological and Toxin Weapons Convention (BWC) and Implementation of UN Security Council Resolution 1540 (2004) -Campaign in support of the negotiation of a treaty prohibiting fully autonumous weapons (FAW) (added in 2020)

tag.narrative: 14.4 - By 2020, effectively regulate harvesting and end overfishing, illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing and destructive fishing practices and implement science-based management plans, in order to restore fish stocks in the shortest time feasible, at least to levels that can produce maximum sustainable yield as determined by their biological characteristics.

14.4 - Senast 2020 införa en effektiv fångstreglering och stoppa överfiske, olagligt, orapporterat och oreglerat fiske liksom destruktiva fiskemetoder samt genomföra vetenskapligt baserade förvaltningsplaner i syfte att återställa fiskbestånden så snabbt som möjligt, åtminstone till de nivåer som kan producera maximalt hållbart uttag, fastställt utifrån deras biologiska egenskaper.
16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.8 - Broaden and strengthen the participation of developing countries in the institutions of global governance.
16.8 - Utvidga och stärka utvecklingsländernas deltagande i institutionerna för global styrning.
16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

title.narrative: Grant agreement between Sida and PGA 2019-2021

description.narrative: Examples of some of the main results so far during the implementation period include: -Support provided to at-risk parliamentarians to protect democratic systems and prevent violations of the fundamental rights of parliamentarians and their constituents for example through joining or initating petitions, issuing statements or introducing resolutions. -Advocacy and activities performed for universal ratification and effective implementation of the Rome Statute of the ICC but also to combat anti-ICC backlash and enchance ICC's functioning. This work contributed during the implementation period for example to the accession of Kiribati to the Rome Statute and to several states taking significant steps towards implementation legislation and co-operation agreements, including Ukraine, CAR, Ecuador, the Gambia and Paraguay. -Advocacy and activities performed for efforts towards the abolition of the death penalty, including through provision of technical assistance. -Advocacy and activites performed for ending impunity for crimes committed and their related HR violations on the world's oceans, incuding within illegal, unregulated and unreported (IUU) fishing and sustainable small-scale fisheries. These included for example discussions and trainings on the "Three treaties to End Illegal Fishing" leading to PGA members posting parliamentary questions in their national parliaments on the ratification and implementation status of the treaties. -Work with civil society partners to sensitize and mobilize parliamentarians against discrimination based on Sexual orientation and gender identity (SOGI) -Advocacy and activities performed for universal ratification and effective implementation of the Arms Trade Treaty (ATT) contributing to for example the ratification of the ATT by Palau and Botswana ratified the ATT and Botswana and to other states, including Colombia and Ecuador taken steps towards accession. -Advocacy and outreach on the Biological and Toxin Weapons Convention (BWC) and the UNSC resolution 1540 contributing to the ratification of the BWC by Tanzania and progress towards accession in Kiribati and Tuvalu as well as to several states submitting its first report on implementation to the UNSCR 1540 Committe. The SOGI campaign continues to be an important part of PGA's work and Sida notes from PGA lessons learnt that even when a parliamentarian is supportive of LGBTI rights privately and/or abroad, this does not necessarily mean they will show their support publicly in their own countries. However there is an important role for both categories of MPs: those who take concrete actions for the SOGI campaign objectives; and those “quiet supporters” who, through the sensitization efforts of PGA, refrain from speaking - or voting - against LGBTI-supportive legislation. Sida notes the continued strong anti-ICC sentiments so far during the implementation period that PGA is working within, which can negatively impact policy-makers’ willingness to advance the ratification of the Rome Statute or to be receptive to supporting the ICC implementation legislation. Moreover, external factors, in the form of implicit or explicit pressures from powerful Non-Party States, can also significantly effect the ICC campaign. As mentioned above PGA continues to engage in the ongoing ICC reform process, encouraging States Parties to take part in shaping the Court’s future direction, while emphasizing the need for judicial independence and prosecutorial autonomy with regard to case selection. Sida notes that a main challenge continues to be that PGA works in contexts where there are continously competing interests, for member parliamentarians as well as for the population in general, with respect to the goals of PGA's campaigns, for example in relation to political instability, electoral priorities, security crisis or the socio-economic situation.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
